review.title: Causal Discovery from Subsampled Time Series Data by Constraint Optimization
review.abstract: This paper focuses on causal structure estimation from time series data in which measurements are obtained at a coarser timescale than the causal timescale of the underlying system. Previous work has shown that such sub-sampling can lead to significant errors about the system's causal structure if not properly taken into account. In this paper, we first consider the search for the system timescale causal structures that correspond to a given measurement timescale structure. We provide a constraint satisfaction procedure whose computational performance is several orders of magnitude better than previous approaches, and that has considerably broader applicability. We then consider finite sample data as input, and propose the first constraint optimization approach for recovering the system timescale causal structure. This algorithm optimally recovers from possible conflicts due to statistical errors. More generally, these advances allow for a robust and non-parametric estimation of system timescale causal structures from subsampled time series data.
histories: International Conference on Probabilistic Graphical Models, PGM 2016

metadata.title: Causal Discovery from Subsampled Time Series Data by Constraint Optimization

sections.text: This work focuses on the estimation of causal structures based on time series data, where measurements are made in a rough timeframe than the causal timeframe of the underlying system. Previous work has shown that such a subsample can lead to significant errors about the causal structure of the system if not adequately considered. In this work, we first consider the search for causal structures on the system timeline that correspond to a given timeline structure. We offer a constraint satisfaction method, whose computing power is several orders of magnitude better than previous approaches. We then consider finite sample data as input and propose the first approach to optimize limitations for restoring the causal structure to the system timeline. This algorithm optimally recovers from possible conflicts due to statistical errors. sections.heading: 3.2 A SAT-Based Approach
sections.text: The first exact search algorithm for finding the G1s that are consistent with a particular problem was presented by Plis et al. (2015b); it represents the current state of the art. Their approach implements a specialized method of depth testing for the problem, using domain specific polynomial time-space pruning techniques. As an alternative, we present here a Boolean satisfaction solution for the search for a G1 that is guaranteed to be consistent with H (if such a G1 exists). Our approach is not only simpler than the approach of Plis et al. (2015b), but as we will show, it also significantly improves the state of the art in terms of time efficiency and scalability.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: Our approach considerably improves the state of the art; in the simplest case (subsampling rate u = 2), we expanded scalability by several orders of magnitude. Furthermore, our method of managing different or unknown subsampling rates is generalized in a computationally efficient way. In contrast to previous methods, our method can work directly with finite samples, and we presented approaches that optimally restore conflicts resulting from statistical errors. We expect that this much simpler approach will enable the relativization of additional assumptions over the model space in the future. In particular, we plan to use this framework to learn the causal structure of the system timescale from subsampling data when latent time series thwart our observations.
